body.head.byline: By VIVIAN S. TOY; With Valerie Cotsalas, Suzanne Hamlin and Lisa Prevost

abstract.p: Sampling of housing on market in New York City metropolitan area; photos (M)

block.p: Long Beach Condo $879,000
NASSAU: 260 West Broadway

A two-bedroom, two-bath condo on the fifth floor of the Meridian, a new oceanfront building with 24-hour concierge service and a pool. Two indoor parking spaces and a one-year membership at a nearby gym are included. Barbara Ruotolo, Topper Realty (516) 286-9527; www.topperrealestate.com
COMMON CHARGE: $384 a month; taxes: $12,000 a year
PROS: The building is next to the boardwalk and the beach, and within walking distance of the train station.
CONS: The terrace is on the side of the building, so the ocean view comes with a parking lot in the foreground.
Arts and Crafts Bungalow $1,199,000
BROOKLYN: 678 East 22nd Street (near Farragut Road)

A detached house near Brooklyn College with five bedrooms, one full and two half baths, a garden, a deck, a garage and a porch. Brooklyn Properties (718) 788-3888; www.Brooklynproperties.com. Open house, Saturday and Sunday, 12 to 2 p.m.
TAXES: $2,942 a year

PROS: Meticulously restored inside and out, this perfectly proportioned house has the original center staircase, leaded glass windows, beamed ceilings, a decorative mantel and a butler's pantry as well as an updated eat-in kitchen.
CONS: There is only one full bath.
Upper East Side Condo $925,000
MANHATTAN: 225 East 86th Street (between Second and Third Avenues), #1203
A one-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath unit with a washer/dryer in a doorman building. Lauren Zidel (212) 585-4558, Iris Klatsky (212) 452-4407, Stribling & Associates; www.stribling.com
COMMON CHARGE: $1,156 a month; taxes: $825 a month
PROS: The apartment has open city views, which can best be appreciated from the spacious terrace, and a dining solarium. A walk-in closet and additional built-ins provide plenty of storage.
CONS: Some buyers might find the layout, which is spread out over four levels, a bit too quirky.
Waterfront Contemporary $2,295,000
CONNECTICUT: 274 Pine Creek Avenue, Fairfield

A five-year-old cypress-clad contemporary designed by Roger Ferris & Partners with two large bedrooms, two and a half baths, floor-to-ceiling built-ins, gas fireplace and radiant-heat floors. Charles Zylstra, Nicholas H. Fingelly Real Estate (203) 257-5727, www.fingelly.com
TAXES: $19,180 a year
PROS: The angled spaces make this house visually arresting. Horizontal cypress louvers and remote-controlled shades afford privacy.
CONS: The house would not lend itself to a third bedroom. Although the garage holds two cars, it is of older construction and is across the street.
Garment District Loft $1,795,000
MANHATTAN: 28 West 38th Street (between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas), #3W
A two-bedroom, two-bath floor-through co-op with a washer and dryer for sale by the owner, a broker. Jim Gricar, Brown Harris Stevens (212) 588-5660; www.brownharrisstevens.com
MAINTENANCE: $1,943 a month

PROS: This airy loft is made for entertaining. The living room has a built-in media system that includes a 72-inch flat-screen digital television. The open kitchen comes with Viking appliances, a walk-in pantry and two-inch-thick marble counters. In addition to the dining area, there is a lounge area that could be converted to a small third bedroom. The bathrooms have been sleekly renovated with limestone and bluestone tile.
CONS: The bedrooms face south onto a construction site, where a 10-story office building is being built.
Long Beach Condo $879,000
NASSAU: 260 West Broadway

A two-bedroom, two-bath condo on the fifth floor of the Meridian, a new oceanfront building with 24-hour concierge service and a pool. Two indoor parking spaces and a one-year membership at a nearby gym are included. Barbara Ruotolo, Topper Realty (516) 286-9527; www.topperrealestate.com
